x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement:
Many pharmacies, especially in underserved or rural areas, unknowingly dispense expired or recalled medications due to lack of timely updates, manual inventory tracking, and poor integration with recall systems.
This can lead to serious health consequences, reduced trust in healthcare providers, and legal or regulatory repercussions.
Nonprofit-run clinics and small pharmacies are particularly vulnerable as they often operate without robust systems for recall management.

x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.solution_proposal:
How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

SafeMeds is a ServiceNow-powered solution that connects pharmacy inventory systems with national and global drug recall databases (e.g., FDA, WHO, EMA).

When a recall or expiry is identified, the platform automatically:

Matches affected batch numbers with pharmacy inventory records.

Sends real-time alerts to the responsible pharmacist or clinic admin.

Initiates workflows to quarantine affected stock and notify staff.

Logs all actions for regulatory compliance and reporting.

Offers a dashboard for NGOs and clinics to monitor medicine safety performance over time.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

Integration with national or international drug recall databases (e.g., FDA’s Enforcement Reports API).

Access to pharmacy inventory systems or spreadsheet imports (for initial low-tech adoption).

Role-based access control to ensure that only authorized staff take actions on flagged items.

Support for multilingual interfaces and offline alerts (e.g., SMS/email for rural clinics).

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Variability in recall data formats across regions and countries.

Data accuracy issues from small clinics with manual tracking.

Limited tech infrastructure in some low-income or nonprofit-run clinics.

Change management — training staff to trust and use the new system effectively.

Ensuring compliance with health data regulations (HIPAA, GDPR).
